bibl.title: English translation [from French] of letter from [s.n.] Seguin to the Medical Inspector, Director of the Health Service of French West Africa, February 1, 1923

div1.p: Seguin reports on the use of Noguchi serum and vaccine in French West Africa, and discusses its prophylactic value.

div1.head: English translation [from French] of letter from [s.n.] Seguin to the Medical Inspector, Director of the Health Service of French West Africa, February 1, 1923
div1.opener:
Seguin 3
FRENCH SUDAN.
HEALTH SERVICE.
Bamako,
February 1, 1923.
No. 37.
(Copy)
Seguin, chief physician, 2nd class, Head of the Health
Service of the French Sudan, to the Medical Inspector,
Director of the Health Service of French West Africa.
Dakar.
******
div1.p:
In reply to your letter No. 149 asking for “exact information
as to the conditions under which the stock of Noguchi serum and vaccine
is used”, which stock was sent to me by the Governor of the Ivory Coast
when I expressed a wish for it in telegram No. 121 of October 8, 1922,
confirming the death of Mr. N., postal employee, from yellow fever, I
have the honor of sending you the following information.

list.item:
1. The amount of vaccine received was 800 cc., and the amount
sent to Ségou was 420 cc. The amount of serum received amounted to 1800 cc.,
of which 600 cc. were sent to Ségou.

2. These products, which were sent from Grand-Bassam by
Dr. Bauvallet, director of the bacteriological laboratory, were trans-
ported in an improvised ice-box first by railway to Bouake, where the supply
of ice was renewed, then by automobile from Bouake to Sikasso, where an
automobile sent by the Governor of the Sudan from Bamako with a sufficient
supply of ice met them and carried them to Bamako, where they were immediately
placed on November 8 in the ice-box of the bacteriological laboratory. The
serum and the vaccine were therefore transported under the most favorable
conditions of speed and temperature possible for the perfect conservation.

3. The first parcel of serum and vaccine reached Ségou on
November 9, where the last European to die had been Monsieur.X....of the
Niger Mission, on October 31. A first injection of 2 cc. of vaccine
was given to the inhabitants of Ségou, about 40 in number, on November 10.
The second injection was given on the 14th, or four days later.

div1.p:
It also seemed necessary to vaccinate the nine members of
the Niger Mission, of whom six were in Niamina and three in Sansanding.
These vaccinations were made by Major Alexandre, at whose disposal the
Governor of the Sudan placed a steamer, and they were completed on
November 20.

A Liberian in the service of Dr. Y....., a member of the Niger
Mission, was the last to die of yellow fever, on November 9, the same day
that the first parcel of vaccine was leaving Bamako. This death occurred
in Ségou.

It was therefore impossible to give this Liberian either serum
or vaccine. Since there has been no further case of yellow fever in Ségou,
no trial of the Noguchi serum has been made. I can thus have no opinion
as to the value of the serum, having had no patients on whom to try it.

As to the prophylactic value of the vaccine, the conditions
under which it was used do not permit of any definite conclusions. The
vaccine may have helped to destroy the small focus of yellow fever that
existed in Ségou, but it would not be scientific to affirm it. In fact,
11 days had already gone by since the last European death definitely due
to yellow fever when the vaccine was first injected, and thirteen or
fourteen days had passed since quarters inhabited by the preceding patients
had been abandoned and disinfected, first by burning tobacco leaves and then
by the use of sulphur.

In addition to this, the season was already advanced and the
mosquitoes had become very rare. All these reasons make it impossible to
draw any conclusions as to the value of the vaccine from the anti-yellow-fever
vaccination practiced in Ségou.

In order to determine its efficiency it would be necessary to
vaccinate only a portion of the population in a more intense yellow fever
center, keeping as controls a few persons who had voluntarily offered
themselves for the purpose, and allowing all other conditions to remain
the same for the two groups.

I do not fail to recognize the difficulty of this kind of
experimentation on human beings with a disease as severe as yellow
fever, but this is the only way in which the efficiency of the Noguchi
serum can be definitely determined. Such an experiment is hardly possible
except in permanently endemic centers of yellow fever.
